dt: {bc}not able to sustain or exert much weight, pressure, or strain
{bc}not able to resist external force or withstand attack
{bc}resulting from or indicating lack of judgment or discernment
{bc}not able to withstand temptation or persuasion

dt.t: the spirit is willing but the flesh is {wi}weak{/wi}

dt: {bc}indicative of a lack of skill or aptitude
{bc}wanting in vigor of expression or effect
{bc}deficient in the usual or required ingredients {bc}{sx|dilute||}
{bc}not having or exerting authority or political power
{bc}of, relating to, or constituting a verb or verb conjugation that in English forms the past tense and past participle by adding the suffix {it}-ed{/it} or {it}-d{/it} or {it}-t{/it}

sls: of a noun or adjective declension in Germanic languages
dt: {bc}retaining a lesser number of distinctions in case, number and gender
{bc}bearing the minimal degree of stress occurring in the language
{bc}having little or no stress and obscured vowel sound
{bc}tending toward a lower price or value

pt: {sc}weak{/sc} {sc}feeble{/sc} {sc}frail{/sc} {sc}fragile{/sc} {sc}infirm{/sc} {sc}decrepit{/sc} mean not strong enough to endure strain, pressure, or strenuous effort. {sc}weak{/sc} applies to deficiency or inferiority in strength or power of any sort.
{sc}feeble{/sc} suggests extreme weakness inviting pity or contempt.
{sc}frail{/sc} implies delicacy and slightness of constitution or structure.

pt.t: a {it}frail{/it} teenager unable to enjoy sports

pt: {sc}fragile{/sc} suggests frailty and brittleness unable to resist rough usage.

pt.t: a reclusive poet too {it}fragile{/it} for the rigors of this world

pt: {sc}infirm{/sc} suggests instability, unsoundness, and insecurity due to old age or crippling illness.
{sc}decrepit{/sc} implies being worn-out or broken-down from long use or old age.

et: Middle English {it}weike{/it}, from Old Norse {it}veikr{/it}; akin to Old English {it}wīcan{/it} to yield, Greek {it}eikein{/it} to give way, Sanskrit {it}vijate{/it} he speeds, flees
shortdef: deficient in physical vigor : feeble, debilitated
not able to sustain or exert much weight, pressure, or strain
